Time_Annotation: A tropical low formed in a weak monsoon trough over the Gulf of Carpentaria early on 20 December and the system dissipated on 23 December.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The cyclone made landfall near Gove and emerged offshore near Darwin, both of which are located in Australia.
Main_Event_Annotation: The system intensified to cyclone status later on 20 December, reaching peak intensity at landfall near Gove and again offshore near Darwin.
Hazards_Annotation: The cyclone produced sustained winds of 115 km/h and gusts of over 148 km/h at Gove, with the strongest winds in the southern quadrants causing extensive tree damage.

Event_Names: Wildfire management and fire suppression in California
Start_Date: advent of the U.S. Forest Service's '10 AM policy'
Time_Annotation: Beginning with the advent of the U.S. Forest Service's '10 AM policy', in which it sought to extinguish all fires by 10 AM the morning after their report, the primary method of wildfire management in California has been suppression.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The text specifies California as the location where wildfire management (and fire suppression) practices have been implemented.
Main_Event_Annotation: The article discusses wildfire management and mentions that wildfires (along with indigenous controlled burning) were historically prevalent, leading to the current fire suppression policies in California.
Hazards_Annotation: Scientists note that before European colonization, a large area (between 4.4 and 11.8 million acres) was burned annually due to wildfires and indigenous controlled burning, indicating wildfire as the primary hazard.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: CNN Center was severely damaged, including shattered windows. Later, damage to its atrium’s glass roof and the newsroom windows is also described.
The Georgia World Congress Center sustained serious damage and later experienced flooding while hosting events.
The Omni Hotel sustained serious damage, especially the skywalk between its two hotel towers over Andrew Young International Boulevard.
The facades of the Georgia Dome were damaged while hosting a basketball game.
A Philips Arena parking garage had its facade damaged during a basketball game.

Multiple buildings had windows blown out. Notably, at Equitable Building 300 windows were blown out, SunTrust Plaza caused the relocation of more than 60 people, and the Westin experienced continued window falls.
The historic Rialto Theatre at GSU sustained roof damage that led to water damage inside.
Grady Hospital reported damage to windows along with a power outage.
The King Memorial MARTA station was damaged and trains bypassed it, with buses rerouted as a consequence.
In the Cabbagetown area, a brick loft building lost part of its roof and a portion of its top (fifth) floor.
Another building at The Stacks on Boulevard was damaged; search and rescue personnel were unable to enter, though all occupants were accounted for.
At Philips Arena, despite attendees noticing little disruption, damage occurred to the exterior of the arena.

Time_Annotation: The article states, 'Based on the astronomical definition, winter begins at the winter solstice, which in 2014 occurred on December 21, and ends at the March equinox, which in 2015 occurred on March 20.' It also mentions that many places experienced their first wintry weather in mid-November.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The text notes that a period of below-average temperatures affected much of the contiguous United States and references specific locations such as Pensacola, Florida; Buffalo, New York; Boston; Arkansas; and Oklahoma.
Main_Event_Annotation: The winter is described as 'frigid and prolifically wintry' with temperatures dropping 15 to 35°F below average, which indicates an event of extreme cold conditions.
Hazards_Annotation: The persistent below-average temperatures and record-breaking cold weather, including the influence of a polar vortex, point to a cold spell hazard as outlined under the Extreme Temperature category.

Event_Names: U.S. Winter Outlook; Environment Canada Winter Forecast
Time_Annotation: The article states, 'On October 16, 2014, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Climate Prediction Center issued its U.S. Winter Outlook' indicating winter conditions, and later notes, 'On November 30, 2014, Environment Canada's monthly prediction system produced a forecast for the months of December, January, and February across Canada.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The outlook covers U.S. regions – including the south‐central, southeastern, western United States, Alaska, Hawaii, and New England – and Environment Canada’s forecast covers areas across Canada (for example, British Columbia, Yukon, Northwest Territories, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario, Hudson Bay region, Nunavut, and Quebec).
Main_Event_Annotation: The forecast emphasizes temperature anomalies, noting 'below-average temperatures in parts of the south-central and southeastern United States' and 'above-average temperatures favored in the western U.S., Alaska, Hawaii, and New England,' as well as similar temperature trends in the Canadian outlook.
Hazards_Annotation: According to the Main_Event–Hazard table for Extreme Temperature, the temperature anomalies imply potential 'Cold Spell' conditions where below-average temperatures are forecast and potential 'Heatwave' conditions where above-average temperatures are expected.

It mentions that 'over 400,000 people were without power on November 27' [11] and additionally that 'southern New Hampshire was the worst hit, experiencing up to 200,000 outages' [11] as well as a separate instance where 'over one hundred thousand customers' in the San Francisco Bay Area lost power [17].

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: Due to the storm, over 4,500 flights were canceled and over 400,000 people were without power on November 27 [11].
Southern New Hampshire was the worst hit, experiencing up to 200,000 outages on November 27 [11].
Another storm, fueled by the 'Pineapple Express', knocked out power to over one hundred thousand customers in the San Francisco Bay Area [17].

Main_Event_Annotation: The narrative describes 'four separate winter storms' impacting a broad region with characteristics (e.g., widespread snow, ice, and mixed wintry precipitation) that are typical of extratropical storms/cyclones, as outlined in the hazard association table.

Event_Names: 2015 Northeastern United States Extreme Temperature Event
Time_Annotation: The article mentions that 'Nine states in the Northeast United States had one of their coldest January–March periods on record' and also states that 'Boston failed to reach 40°F for 43 consecutive days, from January 20 through March 3.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The text refers to the 'Northeast United States' and lists several states (e.g., Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Vermont) and cities such as Boston and Baltimore, all of which are part of the United States.
Main_Event_Annotation: The description of record cold conditions—for example, one of the coldest periods on record and sustained below-freezing temperatures—supports categorizing the event as an Extreme Temperature event.
Hazards_Annotation: The event’s emphasis on record low temperatures, including Boston not reaching 40°F for an extended period, indicates a Cold Spell hazard as defined for Extreme Temperature events.

Hazards_Annotation: The hazard is identified by repeated references to rainlessness, drought-affected areas, water restrictions in Sydney, and the overall characterization of 1980 as the driest year on record, all of which point to drought.
